snippet: President Viktor F. Yanukovych was not so much overthrown as cast adrift by his own allies, and Western officials were just as surprised by the meltdown as anyone else.
abstract: New York Times investigation into last hours of former Ukrainian Pres Viktor Yanukovych's reign reveals that his allies deserted him before he could be ousted and that West was taken by surprise by rapid dwindling of support for Yanukovych; Russia has blamed Western support for uprising that led to Yanukovych's ouster; interviews show that many in government, police and security forces were driven away from Yanukovych as he made plans to make peace with protesters.

byline.original: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
byline.contributor: Steven Erlanger contributed reporting from London.

lead_paragraph: President Viktor F. Yanukovych was not so much overthrown as cast adrift by his own allies, and Western officials were just as surprised by the meltdown as anyone else.

headline.main: Ukraine Leader Was Defeated Even Before He Was Ousted
headline.print_headline: Defeated Even Before He Was Ousted
